alert.note: Alert for Butte; Glenn (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 15 at 2:04PM PDT until March 16 at 3:30PM PDT by NWS Sacramento
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in California... Sacramento River Near Hamilton City affecting Glenn and Butte Counties. Sacramento River Below Red Bluff Diversion Dam affecting Tehama County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in California... Sacramento River At Ord Ferry affecting Glenn and Butte Counties. Sacramento River At Vina Woodson Bridge affecting Tehama County. Sacramento River At Tehama Bridge affecting Tehama County. .Heavy rainfall from the past 24 hours continues to produce significant rises on the Upper Sacramento river system. Flood wave has reached Vina Woodson Bridge on the Sacramento River and will continue to move downstream. For the Upper Sacramento River...including Bend Bridge, Tehama Bridge, Vina Woodson Bridge, Hamilton City, Ord Ferry, Butte City, Moulton Weir, Colusa Weir, Colusa Bridge, Tisdale Weir...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Sacramento River at Ord Ferry. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 110.3 feet, Head cuts in 3Bs silt weir start overflow into Butte Basin, flooding dips on Ord Ferry Road west of River Road. Persistent flows at or above this level increase flooding in Butte Basin. Ord Ferry Road and additional roads in Glenn and Colusa counties are closed due to flooding. At 113.8 feet, Design overflow level for M&T, 3Bs and Goose Lake flood control facilities to divert flood flows into Butte Basin. M&T overflows close River Road from Ord Ferry Road to Chico Road. Ord Ferry Road is already closed. At 114.0 feet, Designated flood stage left bank. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:45 PM PDT Wednesday the stage was 113.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 115.0 feet late this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 114.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 114.8 feet on 03/21/2011. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. For more hydrologic information and stage definitions refer to the following web site: wrh.noaa.gov/sto/hydro_data.php The next statement will be issued this evening at 1145 PM PDT.
